awd_titl_txt: RUI: Collaborative Research: Constraints of biomass on innate immunity across terrestrial mammals
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses two long-standing questions in biology, how genomes become phenomes and how organisms maintain stability through change, by investigating how body size affects immune defenses in terrestrial mammals. Although body mass is one of the strongest influences on many physiological traits, effects of body size are not known for immune systems. Through an unprecedented comparative approach, the research tests whether body size explains why some species are more susceptible to parasites and more likely to act as parasite reservoirs, whereas other species are resistant. Specifically, the research will provide new information on how functional forms of innate immunity relate to body size among >150 zoo-housed terrestrial mammal species spanning a broad range of sizes. Results will provide a framework for understanding of mammalian immune variation has the potential to enhance models of disease spread by providing predictions about the level of immune defense expected in species never before studied. The project fosters career development for two young investigators, a postdoctoral researcher, and 8-10 undergraduate research students. Participants will develop outreach activities for zoos and for biology classes at local middle and high schools, to enhance the educational effectiveness of zoo exhibits and lesson plans. These activities will demonstrate how comparative research is relevant to understanding human and animal health.

This project investigates whether and how body mass is related to the architecture of antimicrobial immune defenses in terrestrial mammals, an unstudied aspect of size-scaling. Host size likely affects i) the chance of exposure to infectious organisms, ii) the ability of immune defenses to keep pace with pathogen replication, iii) the ability of host surveillance mechanisms to detect threats in a comparatively large risk space. The project will determine how functional forms of innate immunity relate to body size among >150 zoo-housed species of terrestrial mammals spanning 7 orders of magnitude in body mass. In addition, protein expression for innate immune defenses as a function of body mass among 10 primate species spanning 5 orders of magnitude in size will be quantified. Using zoo-housed animals, which experience similar developmental histories in common environments, minimizes effects of confounding variables inherent to the study of wild individuals. Measuring functional antimicrobial responses is preferable to less direct assays of host defense. The transcriptomic methods will show which innate immune genes, gene networks, and/or gene modules are most sensitive to body mass. This project addresses two Grand Challenges in Organismal Biology, and has the potential to transform how scientists think about host-parasite interactions. The transcriptomic data generated will contribute to other systems biology pursuits, including understanding how size may constrain the evolution of regulatory processes in vertebrate animals. The participants, including 8-10 undergraduates, will develop interpretive displays and exhibits for zoos, and lesson plans for middle- and high-school biology classes to engage and educate students and the public and to demonstrate the relevance of comparative research.

por.por_cntn:
Why are some species more susceptible to and more likely to act as reservoirs for parasites, whereas others are resistant? We explored body size's role in shaping vertebrates' immune defenses. We suspected that host body size affected immune defenses because it affects i) the chance of exposure to infectious organisms, ii) the ability of immune defenses to keep pace with pathogen replication, and iii) the ability of hosts to detect threats in a comparatively large risk space. We found that large mammals and birds had disproportionately more early acting, antimicrobial cells (neutrophils and heterophils) than their small counterparts, supporting a hypothesis that large organisms need greater early and broadly acting defenses (i.e., the Safety Factor Hypothesis). This pattern held for birds regardless of whether samples came from wild and captive animals, suggesting that captivity does not alter the relationship between size and some immune defenses.

Cell counts are a morphological measure of immunity and do not tell us about the functional capacity of defenses, so we also tested the ability of circulating concentrations of sera-based immune components to kill and halt the growth of three species of bacteria. Surprisingly, this functional response scaled proportionately with body mass in >160 species of mammals. This relationship is greater than we'd expect, given that cellular metabolism, a process proposed to regulate rates of biological processes, decrease disproportionately with body mass. We concluded that large animals do indeed protect themselves disproportionately, as predicted by the Safety Factor Hypothesis, because this functional defense was greater than expected given metabolic rates.

We also queried the effects of body size of several species of primates on innate immune regulatory architecture of the blood of each species. We made two significant findings using a novel transcriptomics (gene expression) approach in which we induced simulated bacterial infections in live blood samples. First, we found that innate immune genes had higher priority than other types of transcriptomes; innate immune genes were over- or -underexpressed to a much greater degree (compared to other genes and gene categories) in large than small species. Second, we found that the overall magnitude of the transcriptional response was disproportionately great in large primate species. Large species expressed substantially more innate immune genes than would be expected from their size alone. Together, these two results provide further support for the Safety Factor hypothesis.

Overall, we found that large animals protect themselves against pathogens and parasites more than small animals, but that ability to increase protection seems to be hampered by other physiological processes, perhaps cellular metabolic rate. Our comparative immunological studies reveal insights about the structure of immune systems that studying a single species would not have revealed. By investigating the immune system through the lens of body size, we could apply over 100 years of studies about how body size shapes animal physiology and ecology to inform predictions of how the immune system would differ among species. When integrated into a novel model of host competence we developed, we can use body size to predict which host species are likely to spread pathogenic parasites to new hosts in host-parasite systems with multiple hosts.

Our research also contributed to five broader impact activities. First, we shared our results widely with a scientific audience through scientific presentations and publications. Second, we developed two peer-reviewed case studies on the immune system available to educators through the National Center for Case Study Teaching in Science. Third, students in one principal investigator's animal physiology course made eight displays about how basic science research informers human and animal health that comprised a temporary exhibit at the Museum of Science and Technology in Syracuse, NY. This museum has an annual visitation of ~100,000, and all 2nd-, 5th-, and 8th-grade students from the diverse Syracuse City School District visit the museum as part of their curriculum each year. This activity fostered cross-disciplinary education in science communication for the 30 biology majors who participated. Fourth, undergraduate students at Hamilton College developed lesson plans about how conservation is related to human health, which were disseminated to our 23 zoo partners. These students also created a permanent display on Lyme disease and conservation for the Utica Zoo in Utica, NY. Finally, this grant trained >23 undergraduate researchers, a Master's student, two post-doctoral researchers, and a research associate (many from groups underrepresented in science fields) while launching the career of a female, early-career researcher.
